spanishExample: Ponen las manos en *the fire,* lo cual no es una buena idea.
englishTranslation: They are putting their hands in the fire, which isn’t a good idea.
vocabIncluded: lo cual: "which" without a specific noun (idiom)
ponen:put, they put (Poner, present, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Pones muchas cosas en esta casa.
englishTranslation: You’re putting a lot of things in this house.
vocabIncluded: pones: put, you put (Poner, present, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Póngase esto, *it’ll complement* su cara.
englishTranslation: (formal) Put this on, it’ll complement your face.
vocabIncluded: póngase: put on / become (Ponerse, formal imperative)

spanishExample: Ponlo en *the kitchen* mientras *we cook.*
englishTranslation: Put it in the kitchen while we cook.

spanishExample: Por favor, ¡ponga eso aquí ahora!
englishTranslation: (formal) Please, put that here now!

spanishExample: Por favor, póngase estos *shoes,* los cuales son *Italian.*
englishTranslation: Please, put on these shoes, which are Italian. (formal)
vocabIncluded: el cual / la cual: "which" (idiom / relative pronoun)
póngase: put on / become (Ponerse, formal imperative)

spanishExample: Por favor, ponte en mi lugar.
englishTranslation: Please, put yourself in my shoes.
vocabIncluded: ponerse en el lugar de alguien: "to put oneself in someone's shoes" (idiom)

spanishExample: Puse mucho *effort* con todo mi ser.
englishTranslation: (preterite) I put in a lot of effort(m) with all my being.
vocabIncluded: puse: put, I put (Poner, preterite, 1st person)

spanishExample: Pusieron un *tree* u otra *plant* ahí.
englishTranslation: They put a tree or another plant(f) there.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
pusieron: put, they put (Poner, preterite, 3rd person plural)
u: "or" (synonym for "o", used before a word starting with an "o" sound)

spanishExample: Pusiste eso donde nadie lo había puesto antes.
englishTranslation: You put that where nobody had put it before.
vocabIncluded: había: "had", "he/she/it had" before a participle (Haber, imperfect, 3rd person)
pusiste: put, you put (Poner, preterite, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Puso *the needle* aquí para *draw* sangre.
englishTranslation: She put the needle here to draw blood.
vocabIncluded: para: "in order", "in order to" before an infinitive
puso: put, he/she/it put (Poner, preterite, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Quiere que ese hombre, quien es su padre, ponga más *effort.*
englishTranslation: He wants that man, who is his father, to put more effort.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
ponga: put, he/she/it put (Poner, subjunctive, 3rd person)

spanishExample: ¡Pon esa cosa donde ellos la pusieron!
englishTranslation: Put that thing where they put it!
vocabIncluded: pusieron: put, they put (Poner, preterite, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: ¡Ponte la ropa; tenemos que irnos!
englishTranslation: Put on your clothes; we have to leave!
vocabIncluded: irse: any use of Ir with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "leave"
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Estos plates, los cuales tienes que poner aquí, son muy grandes.
englishTranslation: These plates(m), which you have to put here, are very big.
vocabIncluded: el cual / la cual: "which" (idiom / relative pronoun)
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Le pusimos *drops* en los ojos.
englishTranslation: We put drops in his eyes.
vocabIncluded: le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")
pusimos: put, we put (Poner, preterite, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: María e Ignacio van a ponerse tristes.
englishTranslation: María and Ignacio are going to get sad.
vocabIncluded: e: "and" (synonym for "y", used before a word starting with an "i" sound)
ponerse: any use of Poner with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "become" or "put on"
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Me puede dar trabajo u oportunidades.
englishTranslation: She can give me work or opportunities.
vocabIncluded: me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")
u: "or" (synonym for "o", used before a word starting with an "o" sound)

spanishExample: Mi cabeza dice una cosa, pero mi corazón dice otra.
englishTranslation: My head says one thing, but my heart says another.

spanishExample: Mis seres queridos y yo pusimos nuestras cosas aquí.
englishTranslation: My loved ones and I put(past) our things here.
vocabIncluded: pusimos: put, we put (Poner, preterite, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: No ponemos esas cosas ahí.
englishTranslation: We don’t put those things there.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
ponemos: put, we put (Poner, present, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: No quiero que el bebé se ponga nada en la boca.
englishTranslation: I don’t want the baby to put anything in his mouth.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
ponga: put, he/she/it put (Poner, subjunctive, 3rd person)

spanishExample: No te pusiste la ropa aún; te la tienes que poner ahora.
englishTranslation: You didn’t put your clothes on yet; you have to put them on now.
vocabIncluded: pusiste: put, you put (Poner, preterite, 2nd person)
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: No tiene que ponerse triste por esto.
englishTranslation: She doesn’t have to get sad because of this (m).
vocabIncluded: ponerse: any use of Poner with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "become" or "put on"
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: No tienes que ponerte triste.
englishTranslation: You don’t have to get sad.
vocabIncluded: ponerse: any use of Poner with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "become" or "put on"
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Pon esto en el mismo lugar que ella lo puso.
englishTranslation: Put this in the same place that she put it.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
puso: put, he/she/it put (Poner, preterite, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Pone *the car* en *the garage.*
englishTranslation: He puts the car in the garage.
vocabIncluded: pone: puts, he/she/it puts (Poner, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Si pongo esto aquí, no va a estar donde lo puse antes.
englishTranslation: If I put(present) this here, it won’t be where I put(past) it before.
vocabIncluded: pongo: put, I put (Poner, present, 1st person)
puse: put, I put (Poner, preterite, 1st person)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Tengo que ponerme la ropa para la fiesta.
englishTranslation: I have to put on my clothes for the party.
vocabIncluded: using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Van a ponerse felices cuando pongas esa *song.*
englishTranslation: They are going to get happy when you put on that song (f).
vocabIncluded: ponerse: any use of Poner with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "become" or "put on"
pongas: put, you put(Poner, subjunctive, 2nd person plural)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Voy a ponerme triste, aunque sé que lo va a hacer.
englishTranslation: I’m going to get sad, even though I know he’s going to do it.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
ponerse: any use of Poner with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "become" or "put on"
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Quiere que me ponga en su lugar y haga algo.
englishTranslation: He wants me to put myself in his shoes and do something.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
ponerse en el lugar de alguien: "to put oneself in someone's shoes" (idiom)
ponga: put, I put (Poner, subjunctive, 1st person)

spanishExample: Quiere que pongamos algo para *stop* la sangre.
englishTranslation: She wants us to put something to stop the blood.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
para: "in order", "in order to" before an infinitive
pongamos: put, we put (Poner, subjunctive, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Quiere que pongan sus cosas en *boxes.*
englishTranslation: She wants them to put their things in boxes.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
pongan: put, they put (Poner, subjunctive, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Quiere que yo ponga más *effort.*
englishTranslation: He wants me to put in more effort.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
ponga: put, I put (Poner, subjunctive, 1st person)

spanishExample: Quiero que los ponga en *the sink.*
englishTranslation: I want her to put them in the sink.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
ponga: put, he/she/it put (Poner, subjunctive, 3rd person)
